title: Friday, 17th August 2018

Excel Developer Hi

Excel Developer Can we muck about today?

Otherwise known as the third Friday of August, a day when not a creature was stirring, not even an RNS.

chopper bear pool elon
chopper bear poor*

AA plc (the "Company") is pleased to announce that it has appointed Peel Hunt LLP and Citigroup Global Markets Limited as the Company's joint corporate brokers, to work alongside its existing corporate broker Liberum Capital Ltd.

Kinda odd that AA needs three house brokers in the first place. But then, there are lots of things odd about AA. The balance sheet, the boardroom, the disclosure methods .....

luzh Re global downturns. Do you remember that piece of research about how mobile phones adoption hugely shrunk the volatility of fish prices in an Indian fishing village? What if widespread broadband internet is like that for but the world.

Excel Developer PCA = Principal Compnent Analysis (Glossary for that pic)

That's part of their Horsemen of the Apocalypse thing. They're currently up to seven.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Here's the original five:

BE11:17am

Rapid RMB devaluation; a BoJ-driven JGB sell-off; accelerated flattening of the UST curve due to SPX-driven state and local pension demand; anItaly “fix” by the ECB; and a shift in the Fed’s policy formulation that is growth accommodative and factors in the evolution of “r star.”

Manxish Happy Friday internet friends
BE11:18am

To which they add two more:

11:18 am
BE11:18am

The first is a Brexit shock where the UK and EU negotiators fail to reach a deal ahead of next March’s deadline. Weaker sterling, cuts by the BoE and lower Gilt yields are all logical outcomes, and the worries about a growth shock should also pull core yields lower. Financial stocks should underperform, and second order risks on the perception that this paves the way for future disorderly exits would further fuel risk-off.

BE11:18am

The second supplementary shock looks at the potential for a single sector to generate a larger economic shock. We focus specifically on tech given the potential regulatory catalyst, its direct importance to growth via investment in particular, and the wealth effects in the context of its significant market cap. We show that a drop in tech-related investment would be consistent with slower productivity growth, and estimate the effect of a decline in tech stocks on GDP growth.

Swedish Chef @crackle the Daily Hate doesn’t lead every day with House prices. Sometimes it’s things which cause/cure cancer.
vonB @Swedish Chef - would that include sick building syndrome?
AGA @BE, somehow feels like "classic fears". Meanwhile buybacks are at an all time high
BE11:21am

........... but that's taken us somewhat off theme.

11:20 am
undefined

Management made an attempt of sorts to settle concerns about that patch of land they're buying from Abramovich and his mates in the middle of the middle of nowhere.

It didn't work.

BE11:23am

"Company indifference to investor concerns on project [is] surprising," says Merrill, which draws the inevitable parallel with ENRC.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

After solid execution on the local projects, ENRC went “off-piste”, outside its area of core competence and bought various assets in the DRC. Ultimately, the company lost the confidence of the market and ENRC ended up delisting.

BE11:24am

.... yeah, that rather underplays the ridiculousness of the ENRC story, which involved a lot of trips to Mayfair .....

cracklenpop Let's see what the new Mail editor brings: https://www.theguardian.com/media/2018/aug/11/new-daily-mail-editor-will-strike-tolerant-brexit-note

BE11:27am

Anyway, it appears Credit Suisse has finished reading the Baimskaya press release issued three weeks ago and has said, "hold on, this doesn't look too good"

Excel Developer @Swedish chef: no, the Yes Minister gag is that that means they are a communist dictatorship.
Swedish Chef @shinsin Random Daily Mail headline generator here. Fun for all! http://www.qwghlm.co.uk/toys/dailymail/
BE11:28am

The outlook for KAZ has completely changed following the acquisition of Baimskaya. What we had liked in KAZ was low cost operations driving strong FCF, a rapid balance sheet delevering and resultant debt to equity shift. This has now been turned on its head. Including the Baimskaya project means capex will remain very elevated for the next 8 years and on our estimates FCFs will remain negative over the period driving net debt up every year with net debt/EBITDA rising quickly above 3x as soon as 2020E. All this would be somewhat easier to grasp if we were confident on significantlong term value in the project but with it completely undeveloped, requiring lots of upfront capex and in a region that comes with higher ESG / political difficulties, this is not the case (our preliminary valuation sees a NPV of below $1bn, assuming a range of first quartile net cash costs). We therefore downgrade to Neutral from Outperform and reduce our TP to £6.30/sh from £10.50/sh.

Bluesky21 From memory Kaz debt is completely funded by Chinese development banks
Bluesky21 I think the bull case is that getting copper from Kaz is of strategic importance to the Chinese state due to proximity, so they will never let it fail
Bluesky21 I never understood why that means equity shareholders will necessiarly make money though
BE11:30am

The counter argument from here is that, while the Russian thing is crazy expensive and stupid risky, it's written off by the market already.

Excel Developer @crackle: there is an FT take on that subject https://www.ft.com/content/b706c2c0-a0ac-11e8-85da-eeb7a9ce36e4
11:30 am
BE11:30am

That's the argument Macquarie makes.

BE11:30am

KAZ produced a broadly in-line result which should be modestly reassuring.
The stock is pricing in a significant negative value for the Baimskaya project, which seems harsh relative to our value-neutral estimate, but can be reasonably justified by even modest tweaks in the project’s key parameters. In our view, Baimskaya therefore represents an out-the-money option for investors, while the underlying business remains undervalued. Outperform.

Pharma @Bluesky21. Quite. Or get their money back, for that matter.
BE11:30am

£7.60 target.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

And they have net debt peaking (I think!) at $2,842bn in 2021 ......... which feels a bit toppy on normalised adjusted profit of $700m or thereabouts.

Um .......... I guess we can turn to strategy, given the lack of alternatives.

Robert Buckland at Citi staying confident, sort of. Here's the single par sum.

Bluesky21 “It” being the debt you owe, sorry
BE11:39am

Too Early To Turn Bearish — Unsustainable bull market peaks are associated with runaway corporate investment. While capex is picking up, we only expect 5% growth in 2018. We forecast a 15% increase in shareholder payouts. Capexlite US Justifies Premium Valuation — Shareholder payouts are valued more highly than capex. The US equity market’s low capex/payout ratio (1.1x) helps to justify its high PE (17.3x 2019 EPS). Value Investors Need Inflation — Value investors generally favour cheap capex-heavy markets and sectors. For that strategy to work, they need to see inflation return. Only then will the market rerate capex versus shareholder payouts. IT Stocks: This Is Not 2000 — While comparisons with the last tech boom are tempting, they are premature. Back in 2000, global IT sector capex (+35%) grew much faster than shareholder payouts (+18%). This time round, payouts (+56%) are growing much faster than capex (+14%).

Mouselet I get the impression that TSMC is working on the assumption that new people will not be capexing billions of dollars of new chips from them.
Pharma Wonder if he will write a companion piece when the time comes: "Too late to turn bearish".
11:40 am
BE11:40am

And also:

BE11:40am

Activists buy cheap capex-heavy stocks, hoping to promote a more pro-payout corporate strategy. Capex looks most excessive in EM, Japan and Europe ex UK, although poor corporate governance often makes it difficult to impose discipline.

BE11:41am

Gist here is that low inflation and yield appetite means the market favours returns over investment.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Plus, management's crap at investment.

BE11:42am

Investor cynicism about the capital allocation skills of CEOs may also be a function of bitter past experience. Shareholders have been burnt too many times by corporate overinvestment. Some of the highest investment/payout ratios of the past 20 years have been found in the likes of Telcos, IT, EM, Japan and, most recently, commodity stocks. All have seen subsequent periods of dramatic deflation and collapsing profitability. Over time, it has made sense for investors to Underweight high capex sectors and markets.

BE11:43am

The message to CEOs is still clear – if you want a higher valuation then favour payouts over capex. This is unusual so late in the cycle. Normally, as the bull market progresses, so the best-fit line in Figure 10 becomes flat or upward-sloping. This sends a more expansionary signal to CEOs. In the current cycle, we might expect cheap capex-heavy European and EM equities to rerate versus the more expensive capex-lite US, but that has not occurred.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

Course, there's an argument that QE didn't really work that well because it didn't support capex.

BE11:44am

Cheap cash went towards buybacks

Soundbuy Never too late for a bear to change its spots............
BE11:44am

We have some sympathy with these views. However, there is little evidence to suggest that higher capex leads to higher profits. After all, the stock market with the lowest capex/payout ratio (the US) is also the most profitable. The market with the highest capex/payout ratio (Japan) is the least profitable. It is also hard to see much evidence of a significant upturn in global inflation, which might also support the case that companies have underinvested and capacity constraints are being hit. Finally, recent experience suggests that capex and payouts are not a zero-sum game. Payouts are not high because capex is low. Instead, strong global profit growth in the past two years has helped to boost strong growth in capex and payouts, it’s just that the boost in payouts has been greater.

11:45 am
BE11:46am

........ "there is little evidence to suggest that higher capex leads to higher profits" ............ jeez. I suspect that's probably right, from a top down perspective, but it's a pretty dismal view of late-stage capitalism.

undefined
Excel Developer Newbie question, is capex strongest toward late cycle? Is high capex a warning (sell) sign?
Pharma What a gloriously short-term view. Low investment equals high reported profits, so should be encouraged. What could possibly go wrong?
Excel Developer @Pharma: yeah but you don't want to build a new factory just to see it suffer a fall in orders as a recession gets underway.
BE11:47am

Want more strat? There's nowt else after all.

Excel Developer Fixed Income strat?
11:47 am
BE11:47am

Graham Secker at Morgan Stanley on EM fallout.

BE11:48am

At this stage EM price underperformance is justified by falling relative earnings estimates and, while EM currencies are now down to new lows, EM debt spreads are not yet particularly elevated.

Pharma @Excel, there does seems to be a pattern that capacity investments come on line just in time for the market to change. Probably just perception bias driven by a search for schadenfreud though
BE11:48am

The macro backdrop for European equities is better than it is for EM peers, however Europe is still more exposed to EM than other DM regions. For example, European companies generate 32% of their revenues from EM (versus 14% for US and 24% for Japan) and MSCI EMU has exhibited a greater correlation to EM FX in the last decade than other DM indices.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

So .............

BE11:49am

Materials, Energy, Capital Goods and Consumer Durables have the highest sales exposure to EM and have historically underperformed when EM currencies have been depreciating. Consumer Staples' stocks also have high sales exposure to EM however their defensive characteristics mean that they traditionally outperform when EM assets struggle. In contrast, Financials have little direct EM exposure but have historically fallen when EM risk appetite contracts.

Excel Developer Oh, that's a gem in that grey "however Europe is still more exposed to EM than other DM regions. For example, European companies generate 32% of their revenues from EM (versus 14% for US and 24% for Japan)"
Excel Developer I am bearish on EM and Europe.
BE11:50am

Which is slightly stating the obvious. More interesting perhaps is the list of EM exposed companies that have outperformed of late.
